...interview by Dr. L.H. Thomas with W.E. Davis of Regina, September 1st, 1970.
You see, they didn't have to go and live on the farm. They could stay at home.
But if they were over the 7-mile limits, they were already quite well-off.
There's six months of the year. The other six months they would love to...
Some of them went away to work in the bushes during the winter months, you know,
to get some money to help themselves along, or went out to work on farms and so on.
But they, again, they couldn't start working until they were 18.
That's the time they started to improve their homesets.
Then they received by the time, they said that three years to get their titles.
Then they'd be about 21, you see.
Get their titles on the land.
And when we came here, of course, all they were asking was to cultivate 30 acres in that three years.
That's only just 10 acres a year, see, that was all that was required.
And there was no requirement for any buildings of any amount.
But that's changed, of course, a lot since then.
That's the way it was worked up then.
Yes, yes. Would you say that the first years, the first two or three or four years in the settlement
were particularly hard, tough for the migrants?
Well, no, I wouldn't say they were tough.
No more so than for the settlers, generally.
Of course, the climate was, that was the thing that we had to get accustomed to, you see.
Yes.
Because there you don't get any lower than 30 or, although they had frost there,
and there too, you see, in the Argentine, when we were thinking frost there.
I can remember sleet there.
We were there.
Were there any significant number of people who withdrew, who left the settlement
and either went back to the Argentine or went into work in the towns, Winnipeg, shall we say?
Yes, some returned to Wales, and some returned back to Patagonia and all of that,
and others went to various places in Canada.
Yes.
Now, am I right in thinking that very few of the people spoke anything but Spanish and Welsh initially?
Were there just very few English speakers?
There weren't very many.
No.
No, there were very few.
Of course, my mother was very fluent in English.
She'd been teaching in Wales before coming out.
She was very fluent.
Of course, her father, he didn't have any hard-earned education at all, you know,
because he was half-dead before he was six.
And then there was, all he had was a little Welsh, but he had to work when he was very young.
Yes, I know what that means.
I gather that the settlers were anxious to establish schools promptly where the children could learn English quickly.
Is that your...?
Oh, yes.
We were here, we came here in June 1902, and the Royal School Districts, number eight out of seven,
it was open on the 4th of May, 1904, so we were practically almost two years before we had a school.
I can remember that very well.
I often wonder, you know, what the teachers of today would do.
There were about 30 pupils there that morning, and you could count on one hand the number that understood English.
The rest of them had no English at all.
We had no English, but we were bilingual then.
We could speak Spanish, I could speak Spanish.
That's the rule, I think, and I speak English today when I first came out,
but that's gone, I was too young to keep it up, you see.
But we kept up the Welsh.
Well, that's the point I wanted to come at now.
The Welsh was kept up relatively well.
Yes, for a good many years.
Yes, yes, yes, yes, just as it had been in the Argentine.
Oh, yes.
Yes.
But unlike the situation originally in the Argentine,
where the idea had really been to establish a separate Welsh state,
that objective had long since been given up.
Oh, yes.
Yes.
I take it from what you say, Mr. Davies, then, that taking that settlement as a whole,
that you could say that the success of the settlers was comparable to the success of settlers
of other origins in adjacent areas.
Oh, I would say so, yes.
Yes.
Yes.
What about the situation when the first war broke out?

A good number, a good number.
Yes, yes, yes.

Yes, yes.

Oh, yes, oh, yes, oh, yes.

I guess I'm one of the few original ones that, I didn't know that people came there in 1923.

you know, the younger generation.
Yes.
Well, now, that was another question that I was interested in.
The children of the Welsh settlers have remained on the land, at least some of them, I take it,
and have taken over the family farm, or have they tended to move away?
Well, there's some of them still, but very few of them remain there on the farm.
There are some, of course.
Yes.
Some have gone to various occupations in them.
Yes.
What would your guesstimate be that 40 or 50 people of Welsh background now farming there, or more than that?
No, I don't think there'd be more than that.
I suppose there was an effort in the early years to keep up the musical tradition of the Welsh.
Oh, yes, that was kept up.
We had our singing festivals and we used to draw them from all parties to come there and just listen to the singing.
We had our competitive festivals there for years.
Instead, we'd see that was held there for a good many years.
Oh, yes.
And then the Welsh Church was organized there in 1904.
Now, which denomination was that?
It was the Calvinistic Methodist.
Not the Calvinistic Methodist, but as they are known today, the Presbyterians.
Ah, yes.
There we are.
In 1905, they became affiliated with a denomination in the United States.
And from there, we had help to keep a minister, and we were alone to build our church.
We built the church in 1910.
Before that, we all had our services in the schools.
And there's another congregation that has their services in the school at the Glendul district,
another five miles away, the other part of Welshmeadow.
Yes, indeed.

Oh, yes. Oh, yes. Oh, yes.

Yes, there's an Anglican church. There's a St. David's Anglican church in Bangor.

I see.
And that's on the farm that my father bought.
He bought a farm with a church situated there.

But some of them were Anglican, were they?
Well, very few of them.

A man came out there in 1906.
I think it was Levenyver Jones.
And he was there in 1907 or 1908, I think, when he left.
And we didn't have a minister at that time.

He left there and he went to Prince Albert when he was in Denver for many years.

I think they were there about six weeks before they started the journey into the valley.
Then they took some of the children by boat.
These would take about two days to go by boat, then go up the Chubut River.
And they were met with a storm, and they were lost at sea, and they were away for about two weeks before they landed.
And they'd run out of water and out of provisions, so it was pretty hard on the children, you know?
I'm not sure whether Dad was amongst that group or not.
Whether he did go with them, or whether he walked with the rest of them.

And about one man would put his stuff in the wheelbarrow, you know, and he'd stand up,
and the whole thing was digging down into the sand.

He couldn't make any headway at all.

And they got this cow and the calf was out sucking, you see.
And the old farmer says, well, we'll have to drive her into the barn, you see, to get this calf.
And he told my sister, you stay there.
And dad had his rope in his hand.
We had no larry at the work.
We just had an ordinary rope, you see.
And this calf went by my sister all this good work.
